intro: Walcuffa pentapetes, commonly known as the five-lobed sandmat, is a flowering plant native to arid regions of Africa and the Middle East. It belongs to the family Malvaceae, which includes hibiscus and cotton. The plant is characterized by its small, pale yellow flowers and hairy, lobed leaves adapted to conserve water. It thrives in sandy or gravelly soils and is often found in dry, open habitats. Due to its resilience, it is sometimes cultivated as an ornamental plant in dry gardens.
